title: COVID-19: Current state of affairs, Omicron, and a search for the end game
content: In this episode, Peter sits down with Drs. Marty Makary and Zubin Damania (aka ZDoggMD), both previous guests on The Drive. This episode, recorded on December 27, 2021, was in part inspired by some of the shoddy science and even worse messaging coming from top officials regarding COVID-19. In this discussion, Marty and ZDoggMD discuss what is known about the omicron variant, the risks and benefits of vaccines for all age groups, and the taboo subject of natural immunity and the protection it offers against infection and severe disease. Furthermore, they discuss at length the poor messaging coming from our public officials, the justification (and lack thereof) for certain mandates and policies in light of the current evidence, and the problems caused by the highly politicized and polarized nature of the subject. Themes throughout the conversation include the difference between science and advocacy, the messaging which is sowing mistrust in science despite major progress, and a search for what a possible “end” to this situation might look like.

title: The Impact of Stress on Chronic Illness, Dementia, and Depression
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more.

title: Physiology of a Stress Response
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., explains the physiology of a stress response and why it’s ingrained in our DNA.

title: Individual Variation in the Response to Stress
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses individual variation in the response to stress and how everyone has a different optimal level.

title: The Impact of Stress on Cancer, Atherosclerosis, Addiction, and Depression
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the impact of stress on cancer, atherosclerosis, addiction, and depression.

title: Comparing Omicron to Delta and other mutations
content: Omicron does not infect lung cells as well as the Delta variant. Omicron is more contagious and causes a more mild illness. There is some natural immunity and vaccine immunity in the South African population. Omicron is very transmissible but seems to cause milder disease.

title: When are there enough mutations to cause new variants to be considered a different coronavirus instead of a variant?
content: There are 4 coronaviruses that circulate year to year and account for about 25% of the cases of the common cold. Omicron may become the 5th seasonal coronavirus. The Russian flu of 1889-1891 may have been caused by a coronavirus that turned into 1 of the 4 seasonal coronaviruses that we live with today.

title: Is there an evolutionary argument or logic to suggest that as the virus becomes more evolutionarily fit it will kill less and spread more?
content: Omicron would be the best (in terms of the virus’s best interest) because it is highly communicative and not lethal. The worst viruses are harder to spread and kill their hosts. This seems to make evolutionary sense.

title: SARS-CoV-2 and the Pandemic
content: SARS-CoV-2 spreads with its asymptomatic and causes severe disease in vulnerable people, which ended up causing a pandemic level of drama. Now Omicron spreads so fast that everyone gets exposed at some point, but it causes less severe disease. Maybe Omicron is nature’s vaccine, providing immunity to those not vaccinated. Maybe this is how the pandemic ends.

title: Measuring Immunity and Protection
content: A Johns Hopkins study shows the importance of T-cell immunity in protection from COVID, which is an under-recognized part of the immune system. T cell immunity is solid against Omicron as it is for Delta. There is not a laboratory test for T cell immunity, and there is not even a commonly available test to measure neutralizing antibodies. Antibody levels go up and down, and having this intense focus on only 1 aspect of the immune system creates a scenario where we’re chasing our tail to keep those levels high. Cellular immunity is still strong when antibody levels wane; it is still preventing severe illness. Focusing on circulating antibodies creates a cascade of surrogate markers that don’t really measure what we’re directly interested in.

title: Policy Questions and Framework for Viewing COVID
content: 10-25% of the population will get infected with a respiratory virus every year because there are many viruses; we’re not going to eradicate these pathogens. A policy-minded framework for viewing COVID is needed. In hindsight, pulling kids out of school in March of 2020 was the wrong thing to do though it was a reasonable precaution. The view of this has changed over time as more knowledge and experience is available.

title: Preventing and Treating Infections
content: Preventing infections (social distancing, masks, vaccines, lifestyle modification) and treating infections (drugs) are crucial in reducing the number of people at risk of dying from infections. Many new therapeutics have not been incorporated into practice everywhere, and this is a glimpse of what is broken in the broader healthcare system.

title: Risk Stratification and Uncertainty in Science
content: It is important to consider the patient’s risk factors and age, etc. when deciding on the best course of action. The difference between science and advocacy is very important, but this line has been blurred. There is uncertainty in science, and this is not reassuring. Conversations about science and ideas of policy are needed.

title: Natural Immunity from COVID after Infection
content: There is a contradiction between policy and scientific evidence regarding natural immunity from COVID after infection. The difference between public health and scientists is causing conflict. Studies have shown that natural immunity works, and we don’t see people get reinfected with severe illness. The hypothesis that natural immunity works should be considered.

title: Studies of Natural Immunity to COVID
content: Studies of natural immunity to COVID have shown that natural immunity was 27 times more protective adjusted for age than vaccinated immunity. The fear in public health circles that if they talk about natural immunity then people may try to get infected; this is risky. The 2 studies cited by the CDC have poor methodology.

title: Reinfection Rates and Severity of Disease
content: In a study in Kentucky, the rates of reinfection in both vaccinated and natural immune group were exceeding low, but the sample size was too low. There is not a lot of evidence published on whether reinfection leads to severe disease and patients needing to be put on a ventilator. Martin Cutler has summarized the 141 studies on natural immunity. Science acknowledges that vaccines are a probabilistic game, reducing the probability of infection and the severity of infection, but that’s all probabilistic.

title: Effects of the Pandemic on Vulnerable Members of Society
content: The Brown University Study on childhood cognitive scores from 2020-2021 showed reduced verbal, motor, and cognitive performance compared to kids born before the pandemic. There is a mental health crisis. Do the policies and mandates make sense? How much do vaccines reduce the ability to spread infection? The difference was the time of virus shedding, 1 day versus 3 days, respectively. These data are not available, but the answer is, they are probably not infectious. Mandates can backfire.

title: Benefits of Vaccination
content: Reduction in disease severity and reduced disease transmission are the benefits of vaccination. Would there be a different policy view if the vaccine didn’t reduce severity of illness by more than 50%, but it reduced transmission by 99%? The main goal here would be dropping transmission and achieving true herd immunity. If the goal is the opposite to reduce severe disease, policy changes dramatically. This shifts from a community level decision risk to an individual level decision.

title: Costs of COVID Policies
content: Anxiety in teens kept at home away from their social network, pressure of using Zoom, and policies are damaging our community and society. Does every child need to be vaccinated?

title: Risks Associated with Vaccines
content: J & J data, 6 cases of VTE (venous thromboembolism, blood clot) in 7 million doses, an incidence of about 1 in 1 million caused the vaccine to be pulled. There is a difference between peacetime and wartime vaccine communication. Danger of letting vaccine rates for measles drop below 90%.

title: Myocarditis risk from vaccination
content: The European authorities have acknowledged the risk of myocarditis from the Moderna vaccine and don’t recommend it for people under 30. The risk of myocarditis is around 1 in 7,600 in males age 15-25; 90% of this complication was clustered around the second dose. Most of the myocarditis was mild but 1 person died (22 years old). A study published in Circulation in July of 2021 stratified risks and benefits by age. For 12-17 year olds, the Moderna vaccine is 3-4x more likely to be associated with myocarditis. The supplemental data came out 2 day ago and it’s 5x. 8-10 cases of myocarditis per million doses; this is 56-69 cases, 38 ICU admissions, and 1 death. More data is needed on this; what about the kids who make an unremarkable recovery? Are there any chronic issues? Some of these kids had preexisting cardiac abnormalities.

title: Benefits and risks of vaccination for young people
content: The label of anti-vaxxer has squashed legitimate questions. A tribalism had developed where a person who questions something that threatens the message of vaccinate everyone is labeled an anti-vaxer. These questions became squashed. The party line (and what CDC says) is the risk of myocarditis in young people from natural COVID infection is much greater than the risk of developing myocarditis as a result of vaccination. But for parents asking these questions about vaccinating their kids against an illness that has an ultra rare rate of death in healthy children, this is a reasonable conversation to have maybe the rate of death from the vaccine parallels the rate of death from COVID in a healthy child. A German study in pre-print of children age 5-17 show that no previously healthy children have died from COVID. This changes the calculus for parents. A conversation is needed; there is not a one-size-fits all strategy.

title: Boosters and policy makers
content: The WHO said the universal booster program threatens to prolong the pandemic and recommends against these boosters. Boosters will increase global inequalities because 93% of the population of poor countries has no vaccine. The FDA bypassed their technical experts to recommend boosters for everbody. The experts said boosters are not needed for everyone over 18. Now there’s enthusiasm to boost teenagers; a lot of the world is not on board with this. Data is lacking for Omicron when Pfizer put out a press release promoting boosters. But this began the group think on promoting boosters for everyone. COVID vaccines are not like the measles vaccine; they do not provide sterilizing immunity. High level herd immunity is not achieved by vaccination.

title: Lack of Honesty and Humility from Top Officials and Policy Makers
content: Discussion of gain-of-function research and Francis Collins' opinion on COVID's origin. The lack of honesty and humility from top officials and policy makers is highlighted, and the importance of honesty and humility in times of crisis is emphasized.

title: Thoughts on Testing: Does it Make Sense to be Pushing Widespread Testing for COVID?
content: The downsides and upsides of testing are discussed, and Peter's opinion on testing is shared. The burden of mass testing and the limited supply of tests are also mentioned.

title: What is the End Point to All of This?
content: The discussion revolves around how to transition to an endemic virus and the need to get people vaccinated. The context of the risk of mild infection of those with some form of immunity is not being discussed, and the people dying are those adults with no immunity.

title: Hospitalization of Unboosted Adults
content: There are about 7,000 people being hospitalized with COVID a day, most of them with no immunity. These are adults who often have a risk factor like obesity. This is a precise problem but we’re holding everyone else hostage.

title: Target Focused Protection
content: The function of COVID is to obtain some outcome that we all agree is reasonable. It’s reasonable that we don’t want bodies piling up in the ER parking lot of the hospital. How do we prevent this? Target focused protection of the groups mentioned earlier. Boosting a 16-year old or a college student is not a high yield way to do this.

title: Lockdowns and Consequences
content: ZDoggMD looks at the hospital numbers in Ontario, Canada and their ICU utilization and wonders why they are going on lockdown. Downstream consequences of lockdowns and draconian policy measures. What does the MMR vaccination rate (and other vaccines) look like for last year? Has there been a shift? ZDoggMD has read anecdotes about the level of kids going in for routine vaccinations dropping in the 80% range. Because parents are frightened and there is a backlash against vaccines in general. What will the outcome of this be?

title: Long-Term Consequences
content: Peter asks, “what is the long term consequence of this for a generation, all the people who have been marginalized, all the people who have been dismissed in their concern, all the people who have been told you are a horrible human being for questioning a vaccine”. Marty doesn’t think our policy makers are getting good medical advice.

title: Polarized Nature of COVID
content: Peter asks how many people are in the middle of these 2 polar opposite views on COVID. On the one hand, people think this is a pharma conspiracy to make more money; the only thing that works is ivermectin. The other group is everyone needs to have a booster every Monday and we never want to see the world as it was in 2019 again until this virus goes the way of smallpox, a zero COVID policy world. How many people are not in one of these 2 groups?

title: The danger of polarizing into two extremes
content: ZDoggMD notes that publicly, there is a reward for polarizing into one of the 2 extremes, and this needs to change. He believes that people are trying to synthesize something that is evolving, and that the woke idea ideologues are common in rational people. This ideology diminished real racism and inequality. We’ve had decades of progress.

title: The need for diverse opinions and open discussion
content: Marty Makary is very concerned about where we are in our current situation. He believes that we need diverse opinions, an open form of discussion, honesty, and humility to tackle the next pandemic. He predicts that pharma will change the language to discuss an annual booster, and that people should talk about and ask about an endpoint to restrictions in schools, criteria to remove masks, a single dose of the Pfizer vaccine for their children or spacing out the doses, and some people with natural immunity should feel good about their immune protection.

title: The potential for another pandemic in the future
content: Looking back at past pandemics for perspective and the potential for another pandemic in the future, Marty Makary believes that we can’t do this with the current polarized echo chamber of the news and politicization of the immune system. He is very concerned about where we are in our current situation, and believes that we need diverse opinions, an open form of discussion, honesty, and humility to tackle the next pandemic.

title: Voices of reason in the space
content: ZDoggMD is a fan of Dr. Monica Gandhi, UCSF infectious disease, who is very much obsessed with getting us back to living instead of living in fear all the time. She’s a pragmatist, very, very smart and data driven. Marty Makary believes that there’s really just one person, and that’s Dr. Anthony Fauci.

title: Managing COVID-19
content: Marty has had different opinions on how to manage the COVID strategy. Amesh Adalja from Johns Hopkins has been correct on India and Delta and so many other things. He was previously on this podcast, #106 – Amesh Adalja, M.D.: Comparing COVID-19 to past pandemics, preparing for the future, and reasons for optimism. Therapies have constantly pivoted in response to new information.

title: Questioning Beliefs
content: Peter notes the type of person who he doesn’t believe is one who says the same exact thing over and over, that doesn’t feel differently about this now versus 6 months ago or 18 months ago. School closures last year are a good example, he doesn’t believe anyone who doesn’t think we got that wrong. Something ZDoggMD points out when he talks about the alt middle is, “you should be able to question every single one of your beliefs because there’s really, you know, if you’re sticking to one single view there, you’re probably missing something”. It gives credibility when someone says they were wrong about something for these reasons, and this is how their thinking has changed. A hedge fund manager who is never willing to change their point of view in the presence of new information is going to end up losing money. It helps to be malleable based on the available data. In medicine the reward is uncoupled from the outcome and this creates mass confusion. It’s difficult to sort out the really good critical thinkers. ZDoggMD agrees that people would benefit from  having the endpoint sync with their thinking. It’s hard to know what the outcomes are for improving healthcare; what is the endpoint?
